docs.title: RForge Orchestrator Plugin
docs.text:
Auto-delegation orchestrator for RForge MCP tools

Automatically analyzes R package changes by intelligently delegating to RForge MCP tools and synthesizing results.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Quick analysis (< 30 seconds)
/rforge:analyze "Update RMediation bootstrap algorithm"

# Ultra-fast (< 10 seconds)
/rforge:quick

# Comprehensive (2-5 minutes)
/rforge:thorough "Prepare for CRAN release"

docs.title: Features
docs.text: ✨ Auto-delegation - Recognizes task patterns, selects appropriate tools ⚡ Parallel execution - Calls multiple MCP tools simultaneously 📊 Live progress - Real-time updates as tools complete 🎯 Smart synthesis - Combines results into actionable summary 🧠 ADHD-friendly - Fast feedback, clear structure, visual progress

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
User Request
    ↓
Pattern Recognition (CODE_CHANGE, BUG_FIX, etc.)
    ↓
Tool Selection (impact, tests, docs, health)
    ↓
Parallel MCP Calls (4 tools × 8 sec = 8 sec total, not 32 sec!)
    ↓
Results Synthesis (impact + quality + maintenance + next steps)
    ↓
Actionable Summary

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
"RForge MCP not found" 

npx rforge-mcp configure
# Then restart Claude Code

"Package not detected" 

# Run from package directory
cd /path/to/package

# Or specify path explicitly
/rforge:analyze --package /path/to/package

"Analysis too slow" - Use /rforge:quick for fast status - Use /rforge:analyze for balanced speed/depth - Only use /rforge:thorough when needed

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:

    "parallel_execution": true,         // Run tools in parallel
    "show_progress": true,              // Show progress bars
    "auto_synthesize": true             // Auto-generate summary
  }
}

  4. Use right command for context

  5. Pre-commit → /rforge:quick
  6. After changes → /rforge:analyze

  7. Before release → /rforge:thorough

  8. Must be in R package directory

  9. Needs DESCRIPTION file

  10. Run from package root

  11. Parallel execution is automatic

  12. No configuration needed
  13. Much faster than sequential tool calls

docs.title: RForge Architecture Guide
docs.text: Deep dive into how RForge works internally: auto-delegation orchestration, pattern recognition, parallel execution, and result synthesis.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
RForge is an orchestrator plugin that intelligently delegates to RForge MCP server tools. It doesn't execute R code directly - instead, it acts as an intelligent coordinator that recognizes patterns, selects appropriate tools, executes them in parallel, and synthesizes results.

Key Innovation: Auto-delegation with parallel execution that completes 4 tool calls in the time it takes to execute 1.

docs.title: Pattern Recognition
docs.text: RForge recognizes 6 primary task patterns:

docs.title: 1. CODE_CHANGE
docs.text:
Triggers: "updated", "modified", "changed code", "implemented"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.impact - Assess change impact - rforge-mcp.tests - Verify tests still pass - rforge-mcp.docs - Check if docs need updating

Example: 

User: "I updated the bootstrap function in RMediation"
→ Pattern: CODE_CHANGE
→ Tools: [impact, tests, docs]
→ Output: "3 packages affected, 42 tests passing, docs up-to-date"

docs.title: 2. BUG_FIX
docs.text:
Triggers: "bug", "error", "fix", "issue"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.tests - Verify fix works - rforge-mcp.regression - Check for regressions - rforge-mcp.health - Overall package health

Example: 

User: "Fixed edge case in mediation calculation"
→ Pattern: BUG_FIX
→ Tools: [tests, regression, health]
→ Output: "Fix verified, no regressions, health score: 85/100"

docs.title: 3. CRAN_RELEASE
docs.text:
Triggers: "CRAN", "release", "submit", "publish"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.check - R CMD check - rforge-mcp.docs - Documentation completeness - rforge-mcp.deps - Dependency validation - rforge-mcp.health - Overall readiness

Example: 

User: "Prepare for CRAN submission"
→ Pattern: CRAN_RELEASE
→ Tools: [check, docs, deps, health]
→ Output: "3 warnings to address, docs 95% complete, ready in 1-2 hours"

docs.title: 4. DOCUMENTATION
docs.text:
Triggers: "document", "docs", "README", "vignette"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.docs - Documentation status - rforge-mcp.examples - Runnable examples check - rforge-mcp.vignettes - Vignette validation

Example: 

User: "Update documentation for new features"
→ Pattern: DOCUMENTATION
→ Tools: [docs, examples, vignettes]
→ Output: "2 functions undocumented, 3 examples need updating"

docs.title: 5. DEPENDENCY_UPDATE
docs.text:
Triggers: "dependency", "upgrade", "version bump", "import"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.deps - Dependency analysis - rforge-mcp.impact - Cross-package impact - rforge-mcp.cascade - Update planning

Example: 

User: "Updated ggplot2 dependency to v3.5.0"
→ Pattern: DEPENDENCY_UPDATE
→ Tools: [deps, impact, cascade]
→ Output: "5 packages affected, update order: base → extension1 → extension2"

docs.title: 6. GENERAL_STATUS
docs.text:
Triggers: "status", "health", "check", "overview"

Selected Tools: - rforge-mcp.health - Overall health - rforge-mcp.git - Git status - rforge-mcp.tests - Test summary

Example: 

User: "What's the current status?"
→ Pattern: GENERAL_STATUS
→ Tools: [health, git, tests]
→ Output: "Health: 85/100, main branch clean, 42/45 tests passing"

docs.title: Why Parallel Execution Matters
docs.text:
Sequential Execution (Old Way): 

Tool 1: 8 seconds
Tool 2: 8 seconds
Tool 3: 8 seconds
Tool 4: 8 seconds
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Total:  32 seconds ❌

Parallel Execution (RForge Way): 

Tool 1: ░░░░░░░░ (8s)
Tool 2: ░░░░░░░░ (8s)  ← All run simultaneously
Tool 3: ░░░░░░░░ (8s)
Tool 4: ░░░░░░░░ (8s)
━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━━
Total:  ~8 seconds ✅

Performance gain: 4× faster (or more with additional tools)

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
RForge uses Claude Code's Task tool to launch multiple background agents:

// Pseudo-code representation
const tools = selectTools(pattern);  // ["impact", "tests", "docs"]

// Launch all tools in parallel
const results = await Promise.all(
  tools.map(tool => executeToolInBackground(tool))
);

// Synthesize when all complete
const summary = synthesizeResults(results);

docs.title: Real-World Performance
docs.text:
From Phase 1 testing on mediationverse ecosystem (5 R packages):

Metric Value Average execution 4ms Maximum execution 9ms Tools called 4 simultaneously Speedup 1,250× under target

Note: These are orchestration times. Actual MCP tool execution happens asynchronously in background.

docs.title: Mode System Integration
docs.text: RForge's mode system controls which tools are called and how detailed the analysis is:

docs.title: Default Mode (<10s)
docs.text:
Tools: Lightweight status checks only 

[health (lite), git, quick-test]
Total: 3 tools, ~8 seconds

docs.title: Debug Mode (<120s)
docs.text:
Tools: Detailed diagnostics 

[health (full), git, tests (verbose), logs, traces]
Total: 5-6 tools, ~90 seconds

docs.title: Optimize Mode (<180s)
docs.text:
Tools: Performance profiling 

[health, tests, benchmark, profiler, bottlenecks]
Total: 5-7 tools, ~150 seconds

docs.title: Release Mode (<300s)
docs.text:
Tools: Comprehensive audit 

[check, tests (full), coverage, docs, deps, health, examples, vignettes]
Total: 8+ tools, ~240 seconds

Mode selection logic: 

if (userSpecifiedMode) {
  use userSpecifiedMode
} else if (pattern === CRAN_RELEASE) {
  use 'release' mode
} else if (pattern === BUG_FIX && contextHasFailures) {
  use 'debug' mode
} else {
  use 'default' mode
}

docs.title: Result Synthesis
docs.text: After parallel execution, RForge synthesizes results into a unified, actionable summary.

docs.title: Synthesis Algorithm
docs.text:
1. Collect Results
Tool 1 (impact): "3 packages affected"
Tool 2 (tests):  "42/45 passing (3 failures)"
Tool 3 (docs):   "95% documented"
Tool 4 (health): "Score: 85/100"
  1. Extract Key Findings
  2. Critical issues (red flags)
  3. Warnings (yellow flags)

  4. Success indicators (green flags)

  5. Generate Summary

  6. Overall health assessment
  7. Priority action items
  8. Quick wins available

  9. Long-term recommendations

  10. Format for Output

  11. Terminal: Rich colors, emojis, tables
  12. JSON: Structured with metadata
  13. Markdown: Documentation-ready

docs.title: Example Synthesis
docs.text:
Input (4 tool results): 

{
  "impact": {"affected_packages": 3, "breaking_changes": 0},
  "tests": {"passing": 42, "failing": 3, "coverage": 78},
  "docs": {"documented": 38, "total": 40, "percentage": 95},
  "health": {"score": 85, "warnings": 2, "errors": 0}
}

Output (Terminal): 

╭──────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 📊 RForge Analysis Summary               │
├──────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                          │
│ Health Score: 85/100 ✅                  │
│                                          │
│ 🎯 Impact:                               │
│    • 3 packages affected                 │
│    • No breaking changes                 │
│                                          │
│ ✅ Tests: 42/45 passing                  │
│ ⚠️  Coverage: 78% (target: 80%)          │
│                                          │
│ 📚 Docs: 95% complete                    │
│    • 2 functions need documentation      │
│                                          │
│ 🔧 Next Steps:                           │
│    1. Fix 3 failing tests (priority)     │
│    2. Add coverage for edge cases        │
│    3. Document remaining 2 functions     │
│                                          │
╰──────────────────────────────────────────╯

docs.title: MCP Tool Integration
docs.text:
RForge delegates to these RForge MCP server tools:

Tool Purpose Typical Time rforge-mcp.health Package health metrics 2-3s rforge-mcp.tests Test execution status 5-10s rforge-mcp.coverage Test coverage analysis 8-15s rforge-mcp.docs Documentation completeness 3-5s rforge-mcp.deps Dependency analysis 2-4s rforge-mcp.impact Change impact assessment 4-8s rforge-mcp.check R CMD check execution 30-180s rforge-mcp.git Git status 1s

Communication: 

RForge Plugin → Task Tool → RForge MCP Server → R Environment

docs.title: Project Structure Detection
docs.text: RForge auto-detects three project types:

docs.title: Detection Algorithm
docs.text:
def detect_project_type(directory):
    has_description = find_files("DESCRIPTION")

    if len(has_description) == 0:
        return "NOT_R_PROJECT"
    elif len(has_description) == 1:
        return "SINGLE_PACKAGE"
    elif all_in_subdirs(has_description):
        return "ECOSYSTEM"
    else:
        return "HYBRID"

docs.title: Ecosystem Detection Benefits
docs.text:
Once RForge knows project type, it can: - Single Package: Focus on that package only - Ecosystem: Analyze dependencies and cross-package impact - Hybrid: Intelligently identify R packages among other content

Example: 

mediationverse/
├── RMediation/DESCRIPTION      ← Package 1
├── bmem/DESCRIPTION            ← Package 2
├── regmedint/DESCRIPTION       ← Package 3
└── pomeMediation/DESCRIPTION   ← Package 4

→ Detected: ECOSYSTEM (4 packages)
→ Enables: cascade, impact, release planning

docs.title: Error Handling & Resilience
docs.text: RForge implements robust error handling:

docs.title: Tool Failure Handling
docs.text:
If one tool fails: 

Tool 1: ✅ Success
Tool 2: ❌ Timeout
Tool 3: ✅ Success
Tool 4: ✅ Success

→ RForge continues with 3 results
→ Notes "Tool 2 unavailable" in output
→ Still provides actionable summary

docs.title: Graceful Degradation
docs.text:
Priority levels: 1. Critical: health, git status (must succeed) 2. Important: tests, docs (try hard) 3. Optional: coverage, profiling (nice to have)

Strategy: 

if (critical_tool_fails) {
  retry_with_backoff()
  if (still_fails) {
    return error_to_user
  }
} else if (important_tool_fails) {
  continue_without_it
  note_in_output("Some data unavailable")
} else {
  // optional tool - just skip
}

docs.title: 1. Caching
docs.text:
RForge caches frequently accessed data:

// Cache package metadata (5 min TTL)
cache.set(`package:${name}:metadata`, metadata, 300);

// Cache test results (until code changes)
cache.set(`package:${name}:tests`, results, UNTIL_CHANGE);

// Cache dependency graph (1 hour TTL)
cache.set(`ecosystem:deps`, graph, 3600);

docs.title: 2. Smart Tool Selection
docs.text:
Only calls necessary tools:

// Skip coverage if no tests changed
if (!testsChanged) {
  skip('coverage');
}

// Skip docs check if no exported functions changed
if (!exportsChanged) {
  skip('docs');
}

docs.title: 3. Incremental Analysis
docs.text:
For ecosystems, analyzes only changed packages:

const changedPackages = git.getChangedPackages();
const affectedPackages = deps.findAffected(changedPackages);

// Only analyze changed + affected (not entire ecosystem)
analyze(changedPackages.concat(affectedPackages));

docs.title: Output Format System
docs.text: RForge supports 3 output formats, implemented as formatters:

docs.title: Terminal Formatter
docs.text:
class TerminalFormatter {
  format(data) {
    return {
      colors: chalk,      // Rich colors
      emojis: true,       // Visual indicators
      tables: true,       // Formatted tables
      boxes: true         // Unicode boxes
    };
  }
}

docs.title: JSON Formatter
docs.text:
class JSONFormatter {
  format(data) {
    return {
      metadata: {
        timestamp: ISO8601,
        version: "1.0.0",
        mode: "default"
      },
      data: structuredData
    };
  }
}

docs.title: Markdown Formatter
docs.text:
class MarkdownFormatter {
  format(data) {
    return {
      headings: H1/H2/H3,
      codeBlocks: "```",
      tables: markdown,
      links: true
    };
  }
}

docs.title: RForge Commands Reference
docs.text: Complete reference for all 15 RForge commands. Commands are organized by category with usage examples and parameter details.

docs.title: Command Categories
docs.text:
• Status & Analysis (4 commands)

docs.title: /rforge:status
docs.text:
Quick ecosystem-wide status dashboard with mode-specific detail levels.

Usage: 

/rforge:status [package] [--mode MODE] [--format FORMAT]

Parameters: - package (optional) - Package name (defaults to current or ecosystem) - --mode (optional) - Status detail level: default, debug, optimize, release - --format (optional) - Output format: terminal, json, markdown

Examples: 

# Quick health check (default mode)
/rforge:status

# Debug mode for detailed diagnostics
/rforge:status --mode debug

# JSON output for automation
/rforge:status --format json

# Specific package status
/rforge:status mypackage --mode release

Output includes: - Health score (0-100) - Package version and path - Git status - Dependencies status - Test results - Coverage metrics

Time budget: <10s (default), up to 300s (release mode)

docs.title: /rforge:analyze
docs.text:
Deep analysis with mode system support and intelligent recommendations.

Usage: 

/rforge:analyze [description] [--mode MODE] [--format FORMAT]

Parameters: - description (optional) - What to analyze or focus on - --mode (optional) - Analysis depth: default, debug, optimize, release - --format (optional) - Output format: terminal, json, markdown

Examples: 

# Balanced analysis
/rforge:analyze "Check package health"

# Debug mode for investigating issues
/rforge:analyze --mode debug "Why are tests failing?"

# Release mode for CRAN preparation
/rforge:analyze --mode release "Prepare for CRAN submission"

# Performance analysis
/rforge:analyze --mode optimize "Identify bottlenecks"

Performs: - Pattern recognition (CODE_CHANGE, BUG_FIX, CRAN_RELEASE, etc.) - Tool selection based on context - Parallel MCP execution - Results synthesis with actionable recommendations

Time budget: <30s (default), up to 300s (release mode)

docs.title: /rforge:quick
docs.text:
Ultra-fast status check using only quick tools (<10 seconds).

Usage: 

/rforge:quick [description]

Parameters: - description (optional) - Brief context for the check

Examples: 

# Morning stand-up check
/rforge:quick

# Pre-commit validation
/rforge:quick "Before committing changes"

Provides: - Basic package info - Git status - Critical issues only - No deep analysis

Time budget: <10s (guaranteed)

docs.title: /rforge:thorough
docs.text:
Comprehensive analysis with R CMD check integration (2-5 minutes).

Usage: 

/rforge:thorough [description]

Parameters: - description (optional) - Analysis context

Examples: 

# Full CRAN preparation
/rforge:thorough "Prepare for CRAN submission"

# Deep quality audit
/rforge:thorough "Pre-release audit"

Includes: - R CMD check execution - Full dependency tree analysis - Complete test suite with coverage - Documentation completeness check - All quality metrics

Time budget: 2-5 minutes

docs.title: /rforge:detect
docs.text:
Auto-detect project structure (single package, ecosystem, or hybrid).

Usage: 

/rforge:detect

No parameters

Examples: 

# Detect current directory structure
/rforge:detect

Output: - Project type: single, ecosystem, or hybrid - Package count and names - Directory structure summary - Dependency relationships

docs.title: /rforge:cascade
docs.text:
Plan coordinated updates across dependent packages.

Usage: 

/rforge:cascade [description]

Parameters: - description (optional) - What's changing and why

Examples: 

# Plan update cascade
/rforge:cascade "Update base package dependency from v1 to v2"

# Version bump cascade
/rforge:cascade "Major version bump in core package"

Analyzes: - Dependency graph - Update order (respecting dependencies) - Breaking changes impact - Test coverage for affected packages

docs.title: /rforge:impact
docs.text:
Analyze change impact across ecosystem packages.

Usage: 

/rforge:impact [description]

Parameters: - description (optional) - What changed

Examples: 

# API change impact
/rforge:impact "Changed function signature in base package"

# Dependency update impact
/rforge:impact "Updated ggplot2 to v3.5.0"

Reports: - Affected packages - Breaking vs non-breaking changes - Required updates - Test implications

docs.title: /rforge:release
docs.text:
Plan CRAN submission sequence based on dependencies.

Usage: 

/rforge:release

No parameters

Examples: 

# Generate release plan
/rforge:release

Provides: - Submission order (base packages first) - Pre-submission checklist per package - Version compatibility check - Timeline estimate

docs.title: /rforge:deps
docs.text:
Build and visualize dependency graph across R package ecosystem.

Usage: 

/rforge:deps [--format FORMAT]

Parameters: - --format (optional) - Output format: terminal, json, mermaid

Examples: 

# Terminal visualization
/rforge:deps

# Mermaid diagram for documentation
/rforge:deps --format mermaid > deps.mmd

# JSON for programmatic use
/rforge:deps --format json

Output: - Dependency graph (directed acyclic graph) - Import vs Suggest relationships - Circular dependency detection - External dependencies

docs.title: /rforge:doc-check
docs.text:
Check for documentation drift and inconsistencies across packages.

Usage: 

/rforge:doc-check

No parameters

Examples: 

# Check documentation status
/rforge:doc-check

Validates: - Exported functions have documentation - Examples are runnable - NAMESPACE consistency with documentation - Version numbers match across files

docs.title: /rforge:complete
docs.text:
Mark tasks complete with automatic documentation cascade.

Usage: 

/rforge:complete [task_description]

Parameters: - task_description (optional) - What was completed

Examples: 

# Mark task complete
/rforge:complete "Implemented bootstrap CI method"

# Trigger doc cascade
/rforge:complete "Fixed critical bug in mediation function"

Actions: - Updates task tracking - Triggers documentation updates - Updates CHANGELOG if configured - Git commit prompt (optional)

docs.title: /rforge:capture
docs.text:
Quick capture ideas and tasks for later (with automatic doc cascade detection).

Usage: 

/rforge:capture [idea]

Parameters: - idea (required) - What to capture

Examples: 

# Capture feature idea
/rforge:capture "Add support for weighted mediation"

# Capture bug note
/rforge:capture "Edge case: NA handling in bootstrap"

Stores: - Idea with timestamp - Context (current package, branch) - Suggested next actions

docs.title: /rforge:next
docs.text:
Get ecosystem-aware next task recommendation.

Usage: 

/rforge:next

No parameters

Examples: 

# Get next task suggestion
/rforge:next

Considers: - Unfinished tasks - Blocking issues - Dependency order - Quick wins - Priority indicators

Output: - ONE recommended task - WHY this task (reasoning) - Time estimate - 2-3 alternatives

docs.title: /rforge:ecosystem-health
docs.text:
Comprehensive ecosystem health metrics with visual dashboard.

Usage: 

/rforge:ecosystem-health [--format FORMAT]

Parameters: - --format (optional) - Output format: terminal, json, markdown

Examples: 

# Visual health dashboard
/rforge:ecosystem-health

# JSON metrics
/rforge:ecosystem-health --format json

Metrics: - Overall health score (0-100) - Per-package scores - Test coverage distribution - Dependency freshness - Documentation completeness

docs.title: /rforge:rpkg-check
docs.text:
R CMD check integration with detailed error reporting.

Usage: 

/rforge:rpkg-check [package]

Parameters: - package (optional) - Package to check (defaults to current)

Examples: 

# Check current package
/rforge:rpkg-check

# Check specific package
/rforge:rpkg-check mypackage

Executes: - R CMD check with standard flags - Parses output for errors/warnings/notes - Categorizes issues - Suggests fixes

Note: This can take 1-5 minutes depending on package size.

docs.title: RForge Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get started with RForge in 5 minutes. This guide walks you through installation, basic usage, and your first analysis.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing RForge, ensure you have:

  1. Claude Code - RForge is a Claude Code plugin
# Check Claude Code version
claude --version
  1. R Environment (>= 4.0.0)
# Check R version
R --version
  1. Required R Packages
# Install in R
install.packages(c("devtools", "testthat"))

# Optional (for coverage)
install.packages("covr")

docs.title: Step 1: Install RForge MCP Server
docs.text:
The RForge plugin delegates to an MCP server for R package analysis:

npx rforge-mcp configure

This will: - Install the RForge MCP server - Configure Claude Code to use it - Set up necessary R environment variables

docs.title: Step 2: Install RForge Plugin
docs.text:
# Via npm (recommended)
npm install -g @data-wise/rforge-plugin

# Or from source (development)
git clone https://github.com/Data-Wise/claude-plugins.git
cd claude-plugins/rforge
./scripts/install.sh --dev

docs.title: Step 3: Restart Claude Code
docs.text:
# Exit and restart Claude Code
# The plugin will be automatically loaded

docs.title: Step 4: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Navigate to any R package directory
cd ~/path/to/your-r-package

# Run a quick status check
/rforge:status

You should see output showing your package health status. If you get an error, check that: - The RForge MCP server is configured (claude mcp list) - You're in an R package directory (has DESCRIPTION file) - R is accessible in your PATH

docs.title: Quick Status Check (<10 seconds)
docs.text:
/rforge:status

Example output: 

╭──────────────────────────────────────────╮
│ 📊 RForge Status - mypackage             │
├──────────────────────────────────────────┤
│                                          │
│ Health Score: 85/100 ✅                  │
│                                          │
│ 📦 Package: mypackage v0.1.0             │
│ 📂 Path: /path/to/mypackage              │
│ 🌿 Git: main (clean)                     │
│                                          │
│ ✅ Dependencies: 5 packages, all current │
│ ✅ Tests: 42 passing                     │
│ ⚠️  Coverage: 78% (target: 80%)          │
│                                          │
╰──────────────────────────────────────────╯

docs.title: Analyze Package (<30 seconds)
docs.text:
/rforge:analyze "Check package health before CRAN submission"

This performs: - Dependency analysis - Test execution status - Documentation completeness - NAMESPACE validation - Git status check

docs.title: Mode System
docs.text:
RForge supports 4 analysis modes with different time budgets:

Mode Command Time Use Case default /rforge:status <10s Quick daily checks debug /rforge:analyze --mode debug <120s Detailed diagnostics optimize /rforge:analyze --mode optimize <180s Performance analysis release /rforge:analyze --mode release <300s CRAN preparation

Example: 

# Debug mode for investigating test failures
/rforge:analyze --mode debug "Why are tests failing on CI?"

# Release mode for comprehensive CRAN check
/rforge:analyze --mode release "Prepare for CRAN submission"

docs.title: Terminal (Default)
docs.text:
Rich colors, emojis, and formatted tables for human readability.

/rforge:status

/rforge:status --format json > status.json

docs.title: Project Structure Detection
docs.text: RForge automatically detects three project types:

docs.title: Single Package
docs.text:
mypackage/
├── DESCRIPTION
├── NAMESPACE
├── R/
├── man/
└── tests/

docs.title: Ecosystem (Multiple Packages)
docs.text:
my-ecosystem/
├── base-package/
│   └── DESCRIPTION
├── extension-1/
│   └── DESCRIPTION
└── extension-2/
    └── DESCRIPTION

docs.title: Hybrid (Mixed Content)
docs.text:
my-project/
├── packages/
│   ├── pkg-1/DESCRIPTION
│   └── pkg-2/DESCRIPTION
├── analysis/
└── docs/

Use /rforge:detect to see how RForge categorizes your project.

docs.title: "RForge MCP server not found"
docs.text:
Solution: 

# Check MCP server status
claude mcp list

# Reconfigure if needed
npx rforge-mcp configure

docs.title: "Not an R package directory"
docs.text:
Solution: 

# Ensure you're in a directory with DESCRIPTION file
ls -la DESCRIPTION

# Or specify package path explicitly
cd /path/to/your-package

docs.title: "R CMD not found"
docs.text:
Solution: 

# Check R is in PATH
which R

# Add R to PATH if needed (macOS/Linux)
export PATH="/usr/local/bin:$PATH"

# Restart Claude Code after updating PATH

docs.title: Performance Issues
docs.text:
If analysis is slow:

  1. Use faster modes:
/rforge:status  # Instead of /rforge:analyze
  1. Check for large .Rcheck directories:
find . -name "*.Rcheck" -type d
# Remove if found
rm -rf *.Rcheck
  1. Limit scope for ecosystems:
/rforge:status mypackage  # Specify single package
